content.text: Measure the length \(l\), width \(w\) and height \(h\) of the block of modelling clay

parts.label: (ii)

content.text: Calculate the volume \(V_{1}\) of the block, using your measurements from (a)(i) and the equation \(V_{1} = l \times w \times h\)

issues: LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode
LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode

content.text: Suggest a possible source of inaccuracy in measuring the block and describe an improvement to the procedure that will produce more reliable measurements of the block
suggestion
improvement
Measure the weight \(W\) of the block of modelling clay, as shown in Fig. 1.2

Calculate a value \(\rho_{1}\) for the density of the modelling clay, using your results from **(a)**(ii) and **(c)** and the equation \(\rho_{1} = \frac{W \times k}{V_{1}}\), where \(k = 100 \text{g / N}\)
measuring cylinder
Fig. 1.3
Pour approximately \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of water into the measuring cylinder
Record the volume \(V_{2}\) of the water in the measuring cylinder
Remove the loop of string from the forcemeter and lower the block of modelling clay carefully into the water in the measuring cylinder as shown in Fig. 1.3
Record the new reading \(V_{3}\) of the measuring cylinder, with the piece of modelling clay in the water
Describe how a measuring cylinder is read to obtain a value for the volume of water. You may draw a diagram to help you

Calculate another value \(\rho_{2}\) for the density of modelling clay, using your readings from **(c)** and **(e)** and the equation \(\rho_{2} = \frac{W \times k}{(V_{3} - V_{2})}\), where \(k = 100 \text{g/N}\)
Suggest which of \(\rho_{1}\) or \(\rho_{2}\) is likely to be the more accurate value for the density of the modelling clay
Justify your answer by referring to the procedure
In this experiment, you will determine the density of modelling clay
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
• Connect the crocodile clip \(\mathbf{C}\) to the free end of the resistance wire
• Switch on. Adjust the position of the crocodile clip \(\mathbf{C}\) until the current shown on the ammeter is as near to 0.40A as possible
• Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across wire \(\mathbf{X}\). Switch off
• Repeat the procedure for \(I = 0.50 \text{A}\), \(0.60 \text{A}\), \(0.70 \text{A}\) and \(0.80 \text{A}\)
Plot a graph of \(V / V\) ( \(y\)-axis) against \(I / \mathrm{A}\) ( \(x\)-axis)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
Measure the length \(l\) of wire \(\mathbf{X}\)
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of each centimetre of wire \(\mathbf{X}\), using the equation \(R = \frac{G \times k}{l}\), where \(k = 1.0 \Omega \text{cm}\)
Give the value for \(R\), to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
A student discovers that the resistance wire becomes very hot when the crocodile clip is connected to short lengths of the wire
Suggest an improvement that would help to reduce this effect
In this experiment, you will determine the resistance per unit length of wire \(\mathbf{X}\)
The circuit has been set up for you
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided
Refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance
• Draw a line about \(10\mathrm{cm}\) from the bottom of your ray-trace sheet. Label this line \(\mathbf{AB}\)
• Mark a point \(\mathbf{N}\), near the centre of \(\mathbf{AB}\)
• Draw a normal to \(\mathbf{AB}\) at point \(\mathbf{N}\), towards the top of the page. Label the other end of this normal line \(\mathbf{L}\)
Draw a line \(\mathbf{CD}\) passing through \(\mathbf{N}\) and at an angle \(\alpha\) to \(\mathbf{AB}\) where \(\alpha = 20^{\circ}\)
• Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line \(\mathbf{LN}\), a suitable distance apart for ray tracing. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\)
• Place the reflecting surface of the mirror on line \(\mathbf{CD}\) and view the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1

• Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) some distance apart so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), and the pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), all appear exactly one behind the other. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\)
• Remove the mirror and the pins
• Draw a line passing through the \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) positions and reaching \(\mathbf{LN}\)
• Measure and record in Table 3.1, the angle \(\theta\) between this line and the normal \(\mathbf{LN}\)
Repeat steps **(b)** and **(c)** for an angle \(\alpha = 35^{\circ}\), replacing pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) in their original positions in step **(c)**
A student suggests that when the mirror is moved, the **change in** \(\theta\) should be equal to twice the **change in** \(\alpha\)
State whether your readings support this idea. Justify your answer with reference to the readings
statement
justification
Suggest two precautions that you took to ensure accurate results from this type of experiment
In this experiment, you will investigate the reflection of light by a plane mirror
ray-trace sheet
A student is investigating the conduction of thermal energy by metals
Plan an experiment to compare the rates at which different metals conduct thermal energy
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment
The apparatus available includes:
strips of different metals, shaped as shown in Fig. 4.1
a test-tube in a clamp stand
a beaker
a supply of cold water
a supply of hot water
The shorter section of each strip of metal can fit inside a test-tube
Write a plan for the experiment
You should:
• list any additional apparatus needed
• draw a labelled diagram of how the apparatus will be arranged
• explain briefly how you will carry out the experiment
• explain how the metals will be compared
• state the precautions which should be taken to obtain reliable results
